item.title: Graham-Cassidy Protects Coverage for Pre-Existing Conditions
item.description:
The legistlation says that nothing a Governor asks for will be approved unless there is affordable and adequate coverage for those with pre-existing conditions.

— Bill Cassidy, interview on Fox & Friends

Claims:

Graham-Cassidy Protects Coverage for Pre-Existing Conditions
The Truth:
States could apply for waivers which could allow insurers to charge those with pre-existing conditions significantly more.

item.title: Graham-Cassidy Would Cover More People Than the ACA
item.description:
I’m sorry he doesn’t understand. Under Graham-Cassidy-Heller-Johnson, more people will have coverage.

— Bill Cassidy, interview with CNN

Claims:

Graham-Cassidy Would Cover More People Than the ACA
The Truth:
It wouldn’t.

Fact Checks:

The Washington Post
Kimmel’s claim that 30 million fewer Americans will have insurance may be a high-end estimate. But already, in 2019, CBO calculations suggest at least 15 million fewer Americans would have insurance once the individual and employer mandates are repealed. Much of that decline might be by choice, but Cassidy insists the gap will be filled and then exceeded in 10 years. Unlike Cassidy, no prominent health-care analyst is willing to venture a guess on coverage levels – but the consensus is that his funding formula makes his claim all but impossible to achieve.
ABC News

The Graham-Cassidy bill would scrap the individual mandate requiring people to buy insurance -– the crux of Obamacare which is so anathema to its opponents –- meaning people would no longer be penalized for not having insurance.

James Capretta, a fellow with the right-leaning American Enterprise Institute, told ABC News the absence of the individual mandate means Graham-Cassidy is “highly, highly unlikely” to cover more people than current law.

item.title: Graham-Cassidy Protects Coverage for Pre-Existing Conditions
item.description:
The protection is absolutely the same. There’s a specific provision that says that if a state applies for a waiver it must ensure that those with pre-existing conditions have affordable and adequate coverage.

— Bill Cassidy, interview with CNN

Claims:

Graham-Cassidy Protects Coverage for Pre-Existing Conditions
The Truth:
States could apply for waivers which could allow insurers to charge those with pre-existing conditions significantly more.

Fact Checks:

The Washington Post
Cassidy is being fairly misleading when he claims “the protection is absolutely the same.” Depending on the state, the protection for preexisting conditions could be the same – or people with cancer or other serious illnesses could find themselves in a high-risk pool being charged extraordinarily high premiums.

item.title: Graham-Cassidy Would Cover More People Than the ACA
item.description:
There will be, I think, more folks covered under this bill than the status quo…

— Bill Cassidy, interview with ABC News

Claims:

Graham-Cassidy Would Cover More People Than the ACA
The Truth:
It wouldn’t.

Fact Checks:

ABC News

The Graham-Cassidy bill would scrap the individual mandate requiring people to buy health insurance — the crux of Obamacare, anathema to its opponents — meaning people would no longer be penalized for not having health coverage.

James Capretta, a fellow with the right-leaning American Enterprise Institute, told ABC News that the absence of the individual mandate means it would be “highly, highly unlikely” more people would be covered under Graham-Cassidy than under current law.

item.title: Graham-Cassidy Protects Coverage for Pre-Existing Conditions
item.description:
If a state applies for a waiver, it must ensure those with pre-existing conditions have adequate and affordable coverage.

— Bill Cassidy, interview with ABC News

Claims:

Graham-Cassidy Protects Coverage for Pre-Existing Conditions
The Truth:
States could apply for waivers which could allow insurers to charge those with pre-existing conditions significantly more.

Fact Checks:

ABC News
There are two issues with this assertion: There does not seem to be any language requiring waiver-seeking states to meet that criterion, and the criterion is open to interpretation.

item.title: ME, VA, FL, and MO Would Get Billions in Additional Funding Under Graham-Cassidy
item.description:
States like Maine, Virginia, Florida, Missouri, there will be billions more dollars to provide health insurance coverage for those in those states who have been passed by by Obamacare.

— Bill Cassidy, interview with CNN

Claims:

ME, VA, FL, and MO Would Get Billions in Additional Funding Under Graham-Cassidy
The Truth:
VA and MO would see temporary bumps, but all four would eventually get billions less.

Fact Checks:

PolitiFact
Two of those four states will see a temporary bump in funding before settling in for a longer-term decline, according to the Avalere study. But the other two states won’t ever see a funding increase under the bill, according to Avalere.
ABC News
A handful of states, including Texas and two of the states Cassidy mentioned – Virginia and Missouri – would in fact end up with a net increase of funding over 10 years, according to a study by the policy analysis group Avalere. But overall, the study found that most states would end up with a net loss of federal funding versus current law.
